definitions: cause physical harm or damage to a person's body through accident or violence
damage someone's reputation, feelings, or prospects through harmful actions or words
examples: The athlete injured his knee during the basketball game
Be careful with that knife or you might injure yourself
False accusations can seriously injure someone's professional reputation
His thoughtless comments injured her feelings deeply yesterday

definitions: make an identical or similar version of something by reproducing its content or appearance
imitate or reproduce someone's behavior, style, or actions deliberately
examples: Please copy these documents before the meeting starts
Students must not copy answers during the examination
Children often copy their parents' habits and expressions
Many artists copy famous paintings to learn technique

definitions: want something strongly or wish for something to happen with intense feeling
feel sexual or romantic attraction toward another person
examples: She desires success in her new business venture
Many people desire wealth but few achieve it
He had long desired her from across the room
The characters desire each other throughout the novel

definitions: communicate or work together with other people in a social or professional context
have an effect on each other when two or more things come together
examples: Children learn social skills when they interact with peers
The new employee struggles to interact with colleagues
Different medications can interact dangerously in your system
These chemicals interact to produce a toxic reaction

definitions: fill a space or container tightly by pushing things into it forcefully
eat food quickly and greedily in large amounts
examples: She stuffed all her clothes into the small suitcase
We need to stuff the pillows with more feathers
Don't stuff yourself with junk food before dinner
The children stuffed their faces with birthday cake

definitions: make an emotional or urgent request to someone for something desperately needed
present a case in a court of law as a lawyer or defendant
examples: The mother pleaded for her child's safe return
He pleaded with his boss for one more chance
The defendant decided to plead guilty to lesser charges
Her lawyer will plead the case before the judge

definitions: identify the nature of an illness by examining symptoms and medical tests
identify the cause or nature of a problem through systematic analysis
examples: The doctor diagnosed her with diabetes after blood tests
It took months to correctly diagnose his rare condition
The mechanic diagnosed the car's problem as transmission failure
Engineers must diagnose software bugs before fixing them

definitions: cause food or liquid to pass down the throat into the stomach
accept something unpleasant or difficult without protesting
completely surround or engulf something making it disappear
examples: The child refused to swallow the bitter medicine
Chew your food thoroughly before you swallow it
She had to swallow her pride and apologize
Workers must swallow unfair criticism from demanding bosses
The earthquake caused the ground to swallow entire buildings
Darkness seemed to swallow the small town completely

definitions: cause a process or action to begin by taking the first steps
formally admit someone into a group or organization through ceremony or ritual
examples: The company will initiate new safety procedures next month
Someone needs to initiate the conversation about changes
The fraternity will initiate new members this weekend
Ancient societies would initiate youth into adult responsibilities

definitions: put limits on what someone can do or have access to
limit someone's movement or activities within certain boundaries
examples: The new law restricts smoking in public places
Parents often restrict their children's internet usage time
Prison guards restrict inmates' movement throughout the facility
Bad weather may restrict flights at the airport

definitions: publicly support or recommend a particular cause, policy, or action
speak or write in favor of something as a recommended course
examples: She advocates for better healthcare access for everyone
The organization advocates environmental protection through peaceful protests
Doctors advocate regular exercise for maintaining good health
Many experts advocate teaching children multiple languages early

definitions: raise and drop the shoulders briefly to express doubt, indifference, or lack of knowledge
examples: He could only shrug when asked about the missing money
She shrugged her shoulders to show she didn't care

definitions: send goods or cargo to a destination using various transportation methods
transport people or cargo specifically by ship across water
examples: The company ships products worldwide within two days
We need to ship these packages before the deadline
They ship cars from Japan across the Pacific Ocean
The navy will ship troops to the conflict zone

definitions: force someone to have sexual intercourse against their will through violence or coercion
examples: The criminal was convicted for attempting to rape his victim
Support services help those who have been raped recover emotionally

definitions: physically stop or bring down an opponent in sports by grabbing or blocking
make determined efforts to deal with a difficult problem or task
examples: The defender managed to tackle the striker before scoring
Rugby players must learn how to tackle safely
We need to tackle climate change with urgent action
She decided to tackle her debt problems systematically

definitions: create music by writing the notes and arrangement of sounds
write text such as letters, poems, or formal documents carefully
form or make up the parts of something to create a whole
examples: Mozart composed his first symphony at age eight
She composes beautiful melodies on her piano daily
Please compose a formal letter to the board members
He struggled to compose his thoughts before speaking
Water is composed of hydrogen and oxygen atoms
The committee is composed of twelve elected members

definitions: give something to someone for temporary use expecting its return later
contribute or add a particular quality or characteristic to something
examples: Can you lend me twenty dollars until Friday
The library lends books for three weeks maximum
The candlelight lends romance to the dinner setting
His presence lends authority to our committee meetings

definitions: estimate or predict something based on current information or trends
display an image or video onto a surface using light
extend outward from a surface or stick out beyond something
examples: Analysts project sales will increase by twenty percent
Scientists project global temperatures will rise significantly
The teacher will project slides during today's presentation
They project movies onto the building wall outdoors
The balcony projects three feet from the building
Sharp rocks project dangerously from the cliff face

definitions: conduct the policy and affairs of a state, organization, or people
control, influence, or regulate behavior, actions, or processes
examples: The elected officials govern according to constitutional law
A president governs differently than a prime minister
Strict rules govern how students behave during examinations
Physical laws govern the movement of celestial bodies

definitions: make something less difficult, severe, or painful than before
move slowly and carefully into a different position or place
examples: This medicine will ease your headache within minutes
New technology helps ease the burden of manual labor
She eased herself into the hot bath water
The driver eased the truck through the narrow gate

definitions: give all or most of one's time, attention, or effort to something
use resources or assets exclusively for a particular purpose or cause
examples: She devotes her weekends to volunteer work
Parents devote years to raising their children properly
The company devotes millions to cancer research annually
They devote half their land to growing organic vegetables

definitions: move quickly or at high velocity from one place to another
cause something to happen or progress more quickly than normal
examples: The car was speeding down the empty highway
Emergency vehicles speed through traffic to save lives
This new software will speed up your computer significantly
We need to speed the approval process along

definitions: exceed or surpass a particular amount, level, or achievement
put something on the uppermost part or surface of something else
reach the highest point or summit of something
examples: Sales topped one million dollars this quarter
The temperature topped forty degrees yesterday afternoon
Top the pizza with cheese before baking it
She topped her dessert with whipped cream
They hope to top the mountain before sunset
Few climbers have topped this dangerous peak

definitions: suffer something painful or difficult patiently without giving up
remain in existence or continue for a long period of time
examples: She had to endure years of painful medical treatments
Soldiers must endure harsh conditions during training exercises
Their love has endured for over fifty years
These ancient buildings have endured through many earthquakes

definitions: deal successfully with something difficult or stressful using available resources and strategies
examples: She learned to cope with chronic pain through meditation
Many students struggle to cope with exam stress

definitions: cause liquid to flow over the edge of its container accidentally
reveal secret or confidential information unintentionally or carelessly
examples: Be careful not to spill coffee on your laptop
The child spilled milk all over the table
She accidentally spilled the surprise party plans yesterday
Don't spill company secrets to our competitors

definitions: express strong objection or disagreement to something verbally or in writing
participate in public demonstration against policies, actions, or conditions
examples: Students protest the new dress code policy strongly
She will protest any unfair treatment at work
Thousands gathered to protest against government corruption peacefully
Workers protest outside the factory demanding better wages

definitions: cause someone to feel happy, satisfied, or content with something
used as polite word when making requests or giving orders
examples: Her thoughtful gift really pleased her grandmother
It's impossible to please everyone all the time
Please close the door when you leave
Could you please pass the salt

definitions: walk in organized military formation with regular steps
walk quickly and purposefully with determination to a destination
walk in organized group to protest or demonstrate for a cause
examples: Soldiers march in perfect formation during the parade
The band will march at tomorrow's football game
She marched into his office demanding an explanation
He marched straight to the principal's office
Thousands will march for climate action this weekend
Civil rights activists marched to Washington for equality

definitions: adjust musical instrument to correct pitch for proper sound quality
adjust settings or parameters to achieve optimal performance
examples: The guitarist needs to tune her instrument before performing
Piano technicians tune pianos twice yearly for concerts
Mechanics will tune your engine for better fuel efficiency
You should tune the radio to find clear stations

definitions: shut something forcefully and loudly with great force or anger
criticize someone or something harshly in strong, angry terms
examples: Don't slam the door when you're angry
The wind slammed the window shut during the storm
Critics slam the new policy as completely ineffective
The media slammed the politician for lying publicly

definitions: declare someone guilty of a criminal offense in a court of law after trial
examples: The jury will convict him of theft charges
Evidence was insufficient to convict the suspected murderer

definitions: increase or improve the strength, value, or amount of something
help or encourage someone or something to be more successful
examples: This vitamin supplement will boost your immune system
The new marketing campaign should boost sales significantly
Her confidence boost helped her win the competition
Government funding will boost small business development programs

definitions: cause someone to do or believe something through reasoning or argument
examples: She persuaded her parents to let her study abroad
Good lawyers persuade juries with compelling evidence presentations

definitions: gradually weaken or damage something's power, influence, or effectiveness
erode the base or foundation of something making it unstable
examples: Constant criticism will undermine employee morale and productivity
False rumors can undermine public trust in institutions
Water erosion continues to undermine the cliff's stability
Termites can undermine wooden structures over many years

definitions: cause damage or have negative effect on something's condition or function
cause physical injury or pain to a living being
examples: Pollution continues to harm the local environment severely
These chemicals could harm your computer's internal components
The accident didn't seriously harm any passengers
Never harm animals for entertainment or sport

definitions: leave out or exclude someone or something either deliberately or by mistake
examples: Don't omit important details from your report
The editor decided to omit the controversial paragraph

definitions: offer to do something without being forced or paid to help others
offer information or opinion without being asked or required to
examples: Many people volunteer at local food banks regularly
She volunteers her time teaching English to immigrants
He volunteered the information about his criminal past
No one volunteered an answer to the difficult question

definitions: attach, fasten, or catch something using a curved or bent device
attract and hold someone's interest or attention strongly
examples: Hook the rope to the metal ring securely
She hooked her bag onto the chair handle
The movie's opening scene will hook audiences immediately
Good writers know how to hook readers quickly

definitions: hang something from above so it remains supported without touching ground
temporarily stop or delay an activity, process, or decision
temporarily prevent someone from participating in an activity as punishment
examples: They suspend decorative lights from the ceiling beams
The bridge appears to suspend over the deep valley
We must suspend operations during the safety inspection
The judge will suspend the hearing until tomorrow
The school will suspend students who break serious rules
The league suspended the player for violent conduct

definitions: seek information or advice from someone with expertise or knowledge
refer to a source of information like books or documents
examples: You should consult a doctor about persistent headaches
Companies consult experts before making major decisions
Please consult the manual for installation instructions
Students often consult dictionaries while writing essays

definitions: make practical and effective use of something to achieve a purpose or goal
examples: Teachers utilize technology to enhance student learning experiences
The company will utilize renewable energy sources exclusively

definitions: protect someone or something from danger, damage, or unwanted access
watch over someone or something carefully to prevent problems
examples: Security officers guard the building twenty-four hours daily
Dogs guard their owners' homes from intruders naturally
Parents guard their children at crowded public events
You must guard your personal information online carefully

definitions: copy data from one computer system to another, typically from internet to personal device
examples: Students can download course materials from the website
It takes minutes to download large video files

definitions: condemn or criticize something or someone very strongly and harshly
express anger or frustration using mild profanity or curse
examples: Critics damn the policy as completely ineffective
History will damn those who ignored climate warnings
She damned her bad luck after losing again
He damned the broken computer under his breath

definitions: give a prize or honor to someone for achievement or excellence
grant something legally or officially after consideration or judgment
examples: The committee will award prizes to three winners
They award scholarships to deserving students every year
The court may award damages to injury victims
The contract awards exclusive rights to one company

definitions: provide funding or capital for a business, project, or large purchase
examples: Banks finance home purchases through mortgage loans
Investors will finance the new startup company generously

definitions: produce a repeated sound caused by reflection of sound waves
repeat or reflect someone's words, opinions, or sentiments
examples: Your voice will echo in the empty cathedral
Footsteps echo through the abandoned hallway at night
Many politicians simply echo their party's official position
The report echoes concerns raised by environmental groups

definitions: write code to create software or control computer operations
arrange or schedule activities or events according to a plan
examples: She learned to program websites using multiple languages
Engineers program robots to perform complex manufacturing tasks
The festival organizers program events throughout the week
Schools program activities to engage students after classes

definitions: publicly declare support or approval for someone or something
sign the back of a check or document to authorize it
examples: Many celebrities endorse products on social media platforms
The organization refuses to endorse any political candidates
Remember to endorse the check before depositing it
You must endorse all pages of the legal document
